summary.seg: Manuscript Gg.2.33 is a composite volume comprising various Greek texts on mathematics, astronomy and geography by Ptolemy, Theodore Metochites, Proclus, Archimedes, Euclid, Theon of Alexandria, John Philoponus, Theodore Meliteniotes, Heron of Alexandria, Isaac Argyrus, Agathemerus and Dionysius of Byzantium. It comprises 13 parts, which now appear partly in disorder.

The texts were copied by three scribes. The majority of the texts were copied by Nikolaos Sophianos, a Greek scribe, printer, and editor from Corfu, who was active in Rome, in Venice and in other cities in the second quarter of the 16th century. One of the manuscript's parts (part VIII) was copied by Constantinos Mesobotes, active in Padua, Venice and Bologna in the first half of the 16th century (manuscripts by him are dated 1508-1533). While it does not seem that Nikolaos Sophianos and Konstantinos Mesobotes worked together (there are no traces of Sophianos' hand in the part of the manuscript copied by him), Sophianos and an anonymous contemporary (hand B) do seem to have worked together: for instance, they alternate in the copy of Proclus' Hypotyposis and Metochites' second book of the Introduction to Astronomy.

Part VI of the manuscript contains the Sketch of Geography by Agathemerus, one of the texts in the corpus of the Minor Greek Geographers. This text was contained in Heidelberg, Universitätsbibliothek, Pal. gr. 398 (a 9th century manuscript), but was lost with the first five quires of the codex; it reached Europe in the 16th century by means of this Cambridge manuscript. In the middle of the 16th century, Nikolaos Sophianos, who copied this part of the manuscript, was sent on missions to acquire manuscripts for the Spanish ambassador in Venice Diego Hurtado de Mendoza. It was probably during his travels that he copied Agathemerus' text from MS Athos, Mone Batopediou, 655 (14th century) on Mount Athos. When Sophianos' manuscript was brought to Italy, 15 copies of the text were produced before 1600 (for more detail, see A. Diller, The tradition of the minor Greek geographers, Lancaster 1952, pp. 15, 17-18).

The parts of the manuscript appear to have been preserved for some time unbound, independent from one another, as the condition of their first and last leaves attests: in various cases these leaves are much more damaged than the preceding and following ones, see e.g. the first leaves of part V, f. 112r, or of part VIII, f. 140r. The leaves of part VIII, copied by Konstantinos Mesobotes, seem moreover to have been folded vertically, another proof that this part was kept unbound for some time. Some of the parts by Sophianos are written on a similar or the same paper; nevertheless, their independence is attested, for instance, by the presence of different sequences of signatures written by the scribe. The tradition of the texts, in some cases, attests the independent origin of the parts, which were copied from different exemplars: for instance it is known that part VI was copied from Athos, Mone Batopediou, 655, part V from MS Paris, Bibliothèque Nationale de France, gr. 2360 , one text of part VII from MS Città del Vaticano, Biblioteca Apostolica Vaticana, Vat. gr. 184 , part XIII from MS Firenze, Biblioteca Medicea Laurenziana, Plut.28.10 .

As has been said, the parts of the manuscript are now bound partly in disorder. Part III, which contains Proclus' Hypotyposis astronomicarum positionum, is formed by ff. 65r-82v and 258r-265v. A quire (quire 318, ff. 258r-265v) has been misplaced and bound inside out. The leaves of part XII are not in the right order, due to the loss of the original structure and succession of the quires. The last quire of part XIII (248r-257v, 107r-111) has been misplaced. It is not clear when these changes occurred but it was certainly before the manuscript received its present binding. On the first leaves of the quires survives a numbering from 2°(f. 122r) to 14° (f. 220r) which attests another order of the quires, different from the original one and from the present one as well. While the details remain to be investigated, this is further evidence of the eventful history of this manuscript.

supportDesc.foliation: Leaves are foliated in modern pencil in Arabic numerals in the top right-hand corner, recto, [i] + 1-265 + [ii].
Passim an earlier pagination, in brown ink, in Arabic numerals, also in the top right hand corner, recto, is visible, see e.g. f. 65r (p. 129), f. 122r (p. 243), f. 132r (p. 263).

condition.p: In fair condition. Yellow and orange stains are present on the leaves throughout the manuscript, in particular near the edges. There are also water and humidity stains throughout, see e.g. ff. 140r-142v, ff. 170r-171v. The edges of some leaves have tears, see e.g. f. 112r, f. 113r, f. [i] recto. Wormholes near the gutter of ff. 227r-[ii] verso.

binding.p: Early modern western binding. Paper and leather (from the spine) on couched-laminate boards, gold tooled leather spine with title Tracts M.S., leather labels on spine with shelfmark.
On the left pastedown there is an annotation in black ink, probably by a librarian: Cambridge University Library MS. Gg.2.33 265 leaves numbered. One flyleaf + one slip of parchment at each end.

accMat.p: There are two paper endleaves, ff. [i]-[ii] (no watermarks are visible). On f. f. [i] verso there are a general title for the manuscript in French, Recueil d'autheurs grecs de mathematique, and an Index of the manuscript's contents in Latin, written by the hand which recurs on the manuscripts owned by Jean-Baptiste Hautin.
On the left pastedown and on the right pastedown are glued two parchment strips ( 75-80 280 ), with a handwritten text in ancient French.

provenance.p: This manuscript, like many others in the CUL collection, was owned by a certain J.B. Hautin, probably to be identified with Jean Baptiste II Hautin, son of the French scholar and numismatist Haultin, Jean-Baptiste, approximately 1580-1640 Jean-Baptiste Hautin (approximately 1580-1640) (on this matter see Jackson 2006, pp. 38-40 with bibliography). On f. [i] verso there is a summary of the manuscript's contents written by a hand which appears in the majority of Hautin's manuscripts, with title Recueil d'autheurs grecs de mathematique.

The manuscript was later owned by John Moore (1646-1714) Moore, John, 1646-1714 , bishop of Ely: number 974 in the handwritten supplementary list of Moore's manuscripts, now MS Oo.7.50(2), compiled by Thomas Tanner (1674-1735) after the publication of Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (1697).

history.acquisition: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 . On f. [i] verso is glued the engraved bookplate made by John Pine for the Royal Library (1737).

recordHist.source: Description (2019) partly draws on A catalogue of the Manuscripts preserved in the Library of the University of Cambridge, vol. 3, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1858, pp. 58-63.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

The text is written in black ink, titles and initials in red.
The title of the first work (f. 1r) is written in majuscule letters.

decoDesc.decoNote: The initial of the first work, in ekthesis and in red ink, is decorated with a vegetal motif with rinceaux.
On ff. 23v and 52r blank space was left for a title and an initial.
Thick red-ink initials in ekthesis mark the start of a new work, or a new section, or a scholion, and sometimes are very simply decorated with points or strokes, see e.g. 3r and 26v.
A clover and a leaf in red ink accompany the title on f. 1r.

history.origin: This part of the manuscript was copied by the scribe Nikolaos Sophianos, who was active in the first half of the 16th c.

msContents.summary: This part of the manuscript contains the Epitomized praise of Ptolemy’s Syntaxis Mathematica by Theodore Metochites. It is a matter of discussion, whether this text constituted the third book of Metochites' Introduction to Astronomy; in the manuscript tradition, it usually accompanies this work (see I. Telelis, review to E. A. Paschos-Ch. Simelidis, Introduction to Astronomy by Theodore Metochites (Stoicheiosis Astronomike 1.5-30) [...], in: Byzantina Symmeikta 27, 2017, pp. 413-423: 417-418). Book 2 of this work is present in this manuscript on ff. 204r-210v. Considering that this manuscript is affected by various cases of misplacements of quires, and given the fact that this part of the manuscript has been written by the same hand (Nikolaos Sophianos, who wrote the first and last part of Metochites' book 2), with the same layout (a single column of 33 lines) and on the same paper (no watermarks), as the part containing Metochites' book 2, it is possible that part II originally followed Metochites' text in part X.

summary.seg: This part contains Proclus' Hypotyposis astronomicarum positionum. The text ends abruptly at the end of chapter 3 on f. 82v, where there is also a catchword in the scribe's hand referring to the next part of the text, which can be found at the end of the manuscript, by the same scribe, on ff. 262r-265r. On f. 262r there is a Greek signature by the scribe, γ΄ (3); the signatures of part 3 are α, β (1, 2). Quires are therefore misplaced. Currently however f. 262 is the 5th leaf of a quaternion (quire 318 ff. 258r-265v: 258-259-260-261 | 262-263-264-265). This quaternion must therefore, at a certain point, have been folded inside out: the original order of the leaves of quire 31 was then probably 262-263-264-265 | 258-259-260-261

msItem.author: Proclus, approximately 410-485
msItem.title: Hypotyposis astronomicarum positionum
msItem.rubric: f. 65r Πρόκλου διαδόχου, ὑποτύπωσις ἀστρονομικῶν ὑποθέσεων
msItem.incipit: f. 65r Πλάτων μὲν ὁ μέγας, ὦ ἑταῖρε, τόνγε ὡς ἀληθῶς φιλόσοφον ἀξιοῖ τὰς αἰσθήσεις χαίρειν ἀφέντα
msItem.explicit: f. 265r ἵνα γένηται καταληπτὸν τὸ μέτρον τῶν ἐν αὐτοῖς.
msItem.note: The final rubric on f. 82v has been crossed out by a later hand

The text is accompanied by diagrams and passim by scholia, marked by signs referring to the corresponding passages in the text: first scholion on f. 65r, inc. Ὑπὸ γὰρ τῶν τηρήσεων ὡρμήθησαν τὰς ὑποθέσεις, last on f. 264v, inc. οἱ δὲ νεώτεροι.

support.material:
ff. 65-82 Western paper, folded in folio. Watermarks: ff. 65-74, Three crescents in a shield and in a circle ( 43 40 ) in the centre of the leaf comparable to Briquet Armoiries 1231 , which is dated to 1529/1533.
ff. 75-82, ff. 258-265 Shape in a circle (Paschal lamb?) ( 43 43 ) in the centre of the leaf, very difficult to discern.

collation.p: Part III consists of 1 quinion and 2 quaternions. The third quire has been moved to the end of the manuscript (ff. 258-265), and has been folded inside out, so that the original first leaf of the quire (f. 262r), on which there is the original signature γ΄ (3), is now the 5th. The original order of the leaves of quire 31 was probably: 262-263-264-265 | 258-259-260-261

signatures.p:
Greek signatures in brown ink, original to the production of the manuscript, from α to γ, on the lower edge, recto, of the first leaf of each quire:
α΄ on f. 65r
β΄ on f. 75r
γ΄ on f. 262r.

Later signatures in modern pencil, probably by a librarian, on the lower margin, recto, of the first leaf of each quire:
A on f. 65r
B on f. 75r
X on f. 258r

collation.catchwords: Vertical catchwords in the scribe's hand on the last verso, lower part, near the gutter, written from the top down.

supportDesc.condition: The leaves are yellowed and show humidity and brown and orange stains near the edges, see e.g. ff. 65r 75r 82v. The edges of the leaves are ripped and have little tears see e.g. ff. 67r-67v 82r-82v. Wormholes on ff. 258r-265v.

The text is written in black ink, titles and initials in red.

The text is accompanied by geometrical diagrams, traced in black ink, with letters and terms in red (see e.g. ff. 68v, 70r, 71v, 259v-260r ).

additions.p: On f. 82v a later hand crossed out the final rubric, writing Reliqua quaere ad finem huius voluminis., referring to the remainder of the text at the end of the manuscript (ff. 262r-265v). The same hand wrote an annotation on f. 262r, Ex Procli libro hypotyposeon quod deesse s notatus est

On the lower margin, right, of ff. 65r and 75r, at the beginning of the quires, is written the number 12°, maybe the remains of a numbering of the manuscript's parts: the same kind of number is written on f. 262r, 7°

summary.seg: This part of the manuscript, which contains Archimedes' Measurement of a circle (Dimensio circuli) followed by the commentary of Eutocius of Ascalon, was copied from MS Paris, Bibliothèque Nationale de France, gr. 2360 (see A. Diller, The tradition of the minor Greek geographers, Lancaster 1952, , p. 15 note 43).

On f. 121v the scribe wrote an annotation indicating as previous owners George Valla and Albertus Pius of Carpi: Πρῶτερον Γεωργίου Βάλλα, ὕστερον Ἀλβέρτου Πίου τοῦ Καρπαίου. The note was however copied from the Paris manuscript, where it refers to its exemplar, Valla's codex of Archimedes (see Diller 1952, p. 15 note 43).

history.origin: This part of the manuscript was copied by the scribe Nikolaos Sophianos, who was active in the first half of the 16th c.

summary.seg: This part of the manuscript contains the Sketch of Geography by Agathemerus, one of the texts in the corpus of Minor Greek Geographers. This text reached Europe in the 16th c. by means of this manuscript. It was contained in Heidelberg, Universitätsbibliothek, Pal. gr. 398 (9th century), but was lost with the first five quires of the codex. The text was copied in the MS Athos, Mone Batopediou, 655 (14th century) and from this codex in MS CUL Gg.2.33 (ca. 1540).

In the middle of the 16th c. Nikolaos Sophianos, who copied this part of the manuscript, was sent on missions to acquire manuscripts for the Spanish ambassador in Venice Diego Hurtado de Mendoza; it is probably during this period that the copying of this part of the manuscript took place on Mount Athos.
When the Cambridge codex was brought to Italy, 15 copies of the text by Agathemerus were produced before 1600 (for all this subject, see Diller 1952, pp. 15, 17-18).

history.origin:
This part of the manuscript was written by the Greek scribe Konstantinos Mesobotes, active in Italy in the first half of the 16th c. The scribe did not sign or date his copy, which should be assigned thus to
the first half of the 16th century.

support.material:
ff. 228-247 Western paper, folded in folio. Watermarks: ff. 232-247, Paschal lamb in a circle ( 42 42 ) in the centre of the leaf, comparable to Sosower Agneau pascal 1 (dimensions are different, as well as some particulars), which is dated to 1569.
f. 231, Three crescents in a shield and in a circle ( 43 40 ) in the centre of the leaf comparable to Briquet Armoiries 1231 , which is dated to 1529/1533.

collation.p: Part XII quire structure is not original. Due to the leaves' misplacement, it is not possible to ascertain the original collation of this part. The present arrangement of the quires seems to be:

signatures.p: One Greek signature in black ink, original to the production of the volume, β, on the lower margin, right, recto, of f. 228r. This signature was written when the leaves were still in the right order.

Later signatures in modern pencil, probably by a librarian, on the lower margin of the first leaf of each quire:
T on f. 228r
V on f. 233r.
These signatures were written when the leaves misplacement had already taken place.

On the basis of the order of the texts, of the position of the unique extant original signature, and of the watermarks, it is possible to hypothesize a possible original structure. On f. 228r there is the signature β (2). This leaf originally, as testified by the order of the text, followed f. 240v. Heron's text starts at f. 233: ff. 233-240 could have formed originally a quaternion, as the position of the watermarks confirms, the first of this part. The present ff. 238-232 (a ternion with a missing leaf), followed, with the binion formed by ff. 241-242 within them, as the sequence of the texts testifies and the position of the watermarks confirms.
Quire [28]8: ff. 233-234-235-236 | 237-238-239-240 (Heron's Pneumatica I,1-32)
Quire [29]8-1: ff. 228-229-230-241 | 242-231-232-? ([ff. 228-242] Heron's Pneumatica I, 33-43; [ff. 231-232] Scholia on Euclid's Elements)
Quire [30]6-1: ff. ?-243-244 | 245-246-247 (blank leaves)

supportDesc.condition: The leaves are yellowed near the edges. Worm holes in the gutter of ff. 228r-247v, and in the upper margin of ff. 242r-247v.

layoutDesc.layout: ff. 228r-230v, 233r-242r A single column of 30-32 lines, mostly 30. 220 130
ff. 231r-232r A single column of 30-33 lines. 235 170

handNote.p: The text is written in black ink.

ff. 231r-232r Hand A,
Sophianos, Nikolaos ca. 1500-ca. 1553 Nikolaos Sophianos (16th c., first half-middle) , (RGK I, 318. See also RGK II, 437; RGK III, 517).
The text is written in brown ink.
The scribe wrote in red the title of the work copied by hand B on f. 233r.

decoDesc.decoNote: Two thick initials in red ink in ekthesis, one is very simply decorated, on f. 233r.

additions.p:
A later hand wrote annotations in Latin in order to indicate the correct sequence of texts and leaves:
f. 228r Tria sequentia folia sunt ex Heronis pneumaticis
f. 231r In librum 5 Euclidis
f. 231v In sextum
f. 232r In septimum
This hand also added in the margins the chapter numbers of Heron's work.

On the lower margin, right, of the first leaf of the quires are written the numbers
14° on f. 228r
1° on f. 233r, probably the remains of a numeration of the manuscript's parts. They were written after the leaves' misplacement took place, as they are written on the first leaf of the current quires.
There are also indications of the pages of an editions of Heron's text by a later hand, in pencil.

history.origin: This part of the manuscript was copied by hand B and the scribe Nikolaos Sophianos, who was active in the first half of the 16th c.

summary.seg: Some of the leaves of this part of the manuscript are misplaced, and are currently bound as ff. 107-111. The texts, all copied by Nikolaos Sophianos from MS Firenze, Biblioteca Medicea Laurenziana, Plut. 28.10 (see J.L. Heiberg, Euclidis opera omnia, 7, Leipzig 1895, p. XXVII), are two incomplete copies of Euclid's Optics in Theon's recension with scholia, and a fragment of Euclid's Phaenomena. The layout is very irregular.

ff. 248r-257v Western paper, folded in folio. Watermarks: ff. 248r-251v, 254r-257v ff. 107r-111v Three crescents in a shield and in a circle ( 43 40 ) in the centre of the leaf comparable to Briquet Armoiries 1231 , which is dated to 1529/1533.

collation.p: Part XIII consists of 1 quinion, and a ternion, missing the 2nd leaf, without loss of text. Due to a misplacement of leaves, the two quires currently are not bound in order.
collation.signatures:
Later signatures in modern pencil, probably by a librarian, on the lower margin of the first leaf, recto, of each quire:
W on f. 248r
F on f. 107r
These signatures were written when the leaves' misplacement had already taken place.

supportDesc.condition: The leaves are slightly yellowed near the edges, particularly f. 248r. Brown stains on the upper edge of f. 252r, near the gutter.

layoutDesc.layout:
The layout is very irregular, a single column of 29-32 lines (53 lines on f. 252r).
200-260 130-175

The text is written in black ink, titles and initials in red. Rubrics are missing on f. 110r
The scribe wrote also some scholia in the margins at ff. 107r-109r .

decoDesc.decoNote: ff. 107r-109r thick initials in black ink in ekthesis, sometimes very simply decorated, see e.g. f. 249v.
There are some geometrical diagrams on ff. 252v-253v, ff. 107r-109r.

additions.p: A later hand wrote annotations in Latin in black ink in order to give information about the texts in the upper margin of f. 107r, in the left margin of f. 109r.
On the lower margin, right, of f. 248r is written the number 6°, probably the remains of a numbering of the manuscript's parts.
There are also indications in modern pencil in the margins, referring to the parts of the text on ff. 107r-109r.

history.origin: This part of the manuscript was copied by the scribe Nikolaos Sophianos, who was active in the first half of the 16th c.
